description:
Ctenopharyngodon idella, commonly known as the grass carp or white amur, is a species of freshwater cyprinid fish native to eastern Asia. It is a large, herbivorous fish that can grow up to 1.5 meters in length and weigh up to 40 kilograms.

Ctenopharyngodon idella is characterized by its large, robust body, small scales, and a large, terminal mouth with no barbels. Its coloration is typically olive-green or brown on the back, with silvery-white sides and belly. The fish has a specialized pharyngeal jaw apparatus with numerous molariform teeth, which allows it to effectively graze on a variety of aquatic vegetation.

This species is widely distributed in the major river systems of China, including the Yangtze, Pearl, and Amur River basins. It has been introduced to many other parts of the world, including North America, Europe, and Africa, for the purpose of aquatic weed control and as a food fish.

Ctenopharyngodon idella is an important aquaculture species, and its rapid growth rate, adaptability to various environments, and efficient utilization of aquatic plants make it a valuable resource for sustainable food production.
